data.title: TextureProgress node has -nan as default Initial Angle value, causes crash upon save
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7 - Stable 2.1 from website

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

When adding a TextureProgress node, the Initial Angle value under Radial Fill is "-nan" by default.

 If you try and save the scene without changing it, Godot crashes. Because of this I'm unable to create an example, but it's pretty straight forward to recreate.

A stranger version of this bug actually occurred in my main project, except it didn't cause Godot to crash. Instead it caused the player (Kinematic) to fall straight through the static body below it. As soon as I changed the Initial Angle value on the TextureProgress bar I was using to a valid value like 0 , the problem went away and collisions worked again.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Add a TextureProgress node to any scene, the default value in the Initial Angle box under Radial Fill will be "-nan". Saving at this point will crash Godot, or if you saved that part of the tree off as its own scene and instanced it, it does other weird stuff 

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: RigidBody2D get_colliding_bodies() not reporting contacts
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7 - 2.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

get_colliding bodies() does not seem to be reporting any contacts in RigidBody2D

**Steps to reproduce:**

every frame, test get_colliding_bodies(), set the rigidbody in a situation you know it will be colliding and observe results

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
(obviously based off of HeartBeast's Tutorial)
[Breakout.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/460289/Breakout.zip)
(debugging info about the ball is printed to console)

data.title: Middle mouse button + Shift defuncts window chrome
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 x64 with Anniversary Update, Godot 2.1 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
As soon as I press the middle mouse button and hit Shift while doing so, either in the Godot engine editor or any game, I no longer see hover effects over my caption buttons, nor does clicking them or the title bar work anymore, e.g., I can't move the window or close it. Alt+F4 is also defunct. The system menu does not open when clicking the window icon.

It sometimes randomly seems to solve itself so that the chrome works again, but that's rarely the case.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Hit the middle mouse button / mouse wheel over the editor or a game window and the Shift key while doing so, and then try to use the window border.

data.title: fixed wrong placement of AcceptDialog Buttons issue-6143
data.body: The Buttons of AcceptDialog, ConfirmationDialog and FileDialog were wrong placed after creation.

data.title: AnimationPlayer: Collapse key tracks into single track
data.body:
My suggestion is to implement a button which would collapse the view of all the tracks into a single track.  The purpose of this is for cutting up a strip of animation which contains multiple 'actions' e.g. a strip which has the walk cycle, attack cycle, jump cycle all in the same strip.

When cutting up a strip now, if there are more tracks than fit within the track window, even if extended, you have to scroll down mid selection to get the tracks that weren't visible.  If the tracks could be collapsed into a single track, you would be able to select all tracks at once.

Look at blender's action/ dope sheet frame tracks.  The top row collapses all of the tracks.

data.title: Added setting to change current script background color, issue 5450
data.body:
Added setting to change current script background color, can also be disabled.

closes #5450

data.title: Itemlist tooltip disable issue 6240
data.body:
Added methods to enabled and disable ItemList's Item's Tooltip.

closes #6240

data.title: Incorrect handling of DPad UP on Ubuntu
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 14.04.03 using Godot 2.1-stable
Gamepad is XBOX 360 controller in wireless mode.
Installed package (dpkg -l | grep xb):
xboxdrv     0.8.5-1      amd64        Xbox360 gamepad driver for the userspace

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When using dpad on a gamepad, pressing UP button doubles as an A button, making any button navigation difficult, as going UP also calls UI_ ACCEPT by default.

**Steps to reproduce:**
On Ubuntu 14.04.03
- run demo project named 'Joysticks'
- press UP on gamepad dpad
- observe buttons

Expected result:
only UP button lights up in the demo
Actual result:
both UP and A buttons light up

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
'Joysticks' demo from samples bundle

I have tested same gamepad on http://html5gamepad.com/ in Firefox, and all seems fine, though button numbering differs from godot one.

data.title: Add show bones checkable menu item
data.body:
Sometimes bones disrupt visibility a lot, specially on small zoom levels. Configuring a smaller width is no solution because you'll probably end up with a bigger zoom and then you'd need to make them wider again.

Defaults to true to keep by default the same behavior.
Self-checks on effective operations on bones (make/clear, IK set/unset).

data.title: Fix Android build (#5645)
data.body:
Well, I've come across the issue some people are getting, too.
As I've found Gradle intermediate library directories gets messy, I've removed the unused specification of a libraries directory for all build types so it now appears to work better.

data.title: Expose additional light/shadow properties to canvas item shaders
data.body:
While working on a `CanvasItemShader` for my game I had the need to write to SHADOW but I needed also to know the shadow color set for the 2D light source. I think this is a must because if for any reason you need to tweak the output shadow color, you have to know the light shadow color.

I also found the `USE_LIGHT_SHADOW_COLOR` macro pretty misleading while trying to follow the code.

Finally I have exposed both input and output shadow colors to the shader graph (as opposed to code shaders these didn't have the input shadow color either).

data.title: enable autoload for command-line scripts
data.body:
fixes #6360

Note that while this might look like a lot of changes, it's only because of indentation (diff without it: https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/6413/commits/8ddc0b697b26797d2d5682a9112dff59c950b22a?w=1). Only real difference is in conditions: autoload code is executed if either `game_path` **or** `script` is non-empty.

data.title: Animation Player stutters when set to continuous between same frames for big sprite sheets and frame > 100
data.body:
Godot v2.1 (tested on Linux and Windows)

When animating a sprite sheet with an Animation Player set to continuous interpolation and two key frames are inserted, both with the same value, the animation jumps to a different frame inbetween. This causes a stuttering in the animation.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Set up an Sprite Sheet with an animation Player. 
Set interpolation to continuous.
Insert a frame at t = 0.1 and the same frame at t = 1.0 (or so).
Play the animation or scrub through the timeline.
The frame will change.

data.title: AnimationTreePlayer don't play autoqueued animations
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
OpenSuse Leap 42.1 64 bits
godot  2.2 alpha custom build 64 bit

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I have setup an animation with auto queue enabled but when the animation ends is not playing next animation in queue by using AnimationTreePlayer.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create AnimationPlayer, add two animations(anim1 and anim2 ), set Next (auto queue) from anim1 to anim2. Add AnimationPlayer to AnimationTreePlayer and animation node with anim1, start AnimationTreePlayer and auto queue doesn't work.

data.title: Always show output panel when debugging
data.body:
Fixes #6029 

Now the Output panel is guaranteed to be visible when hitting F5.

data.title: osx: Support gamepad input.
data.body:
Fixes #3881

Vibration support is not optimal yet as it doesn't try to emulate the "weak" and "strong" motor strength,
but just takes the parameter with the highest value for the vibration gain.

data.title: Vector3.snapped gives incorrect result with negative values
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7 64bit - Tested on Godot 2.03, 2.1 and current sources 

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
What happened: 
`Vector3.snapped` rounds to the higher number (less negative) instead of the closest to the given argument when the value is negative. 

What was expected:
Same behavior/result as `GDScript.stepify` or `Vector2.snapped` (rounded to the closest number).

**Steps to reproduce:**
Running a script with the following lines:

```
    print("original      : ",Vector3(-9.8,9.8,0.6))
    print("V3 snapped: ",Vector3(-9.8,9.8,0.6).snapped(0.5))
    print("V2 snapped: ",Vector2(-9.8,9.8).snapped(Vector2(0.5,0.5)))
    print("stepify       : (",stepify(-9.8,0.5),", ",stepify(9.8,0.5),", ",stepify(0.6,0.5),")")
```

Gives as output:

> original      : (-9.8, 9.8, 0.6)
> V3 snapped: (-9.5, 10, 0.5)
> V2 snapped: (-10, 10)
> stepify       : (-10, 10, 0.5)

The second line has a wrong snapped x value.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.body:

Arch (Rolling Release) Linux. Godot 2.1 32 bit.

Tried out several godot-demo-projects. All crash unexpectantly after pressing the PLAY button.
Errors in console -

**Steps to reproduce:**

New Project -> Open Scene -> Play.
